Hazari Pal.Action: Serves the children first the precious water, showing care and consideration for their needs.
Suppresses his habitual cough, possibly hiding his own discomfort to not worry others.
Hands a rupee and sweets to Vendor #1 despite initial doubt, tries to reassure his family by suggesting all is well after feeling stunned.
Shows a deeply fearful look but attempts to revive the family's confidence.
Gives a rupee to Manooj to buy fruit and carefully watches over his son, warning him to be cautious crossing the street.
Hands Vendor #1 a rupee and sweets despite being stunned, then tries to suggest all is well to his family, showing composure under pressure.
Gives Manooj money to fetch fruit and instructs him carefully to come straight back and watch where he is going, showing foresight and protective care.
His face shows deep fear that he struggles to control, indicating internal insecurity despite external attempts to appear confident.
Agrees to pay only part of the rent immediately with promise to pay the rest later, showing responsibility and trustworthiness.
Accepts help from Gangooly graciously, showing humility and gratitude.
Pays the rent partially, honestly explains limited money but commits to paying the rest once employed.
Trusts Gangooly's promise to find work and accepts the arrangement confidently.
Calmly accepts being threatened by Binal and quietly withdraws with his family without escalating conflict.
Confronts a man who pushes Aloka, standing up for a vulnerable family member.
Tries to assert a fact about a deposit paid amid a hostile dispute, showing some attempt at defending his position.
Looks at Manooj when threatened by Binal, without intervening or standing up strongly.
Shoulders his burden and leads his family toward the river despite uncertainty and adversity, showing resilience and a measure of leadership.
Kneels beside Manooj, strokes him, and reassures him not to be frightened, expressing confidence that they will find work.
Wears a confident smile to calm his panicking family and gathers them protectively into his arms as they face uncertainty at the docks.
Insists on not taking charity from the clerk despite being desperate and three days without work.
Hangs onto the window in panic, showing vulnerability and earnestness in seeking work.
Persistently approaches the jute mill clerk despite being dismissed and pushed away, showing determination to find work.
Unable to secure employment even after pleading, and is hurriedly dismissed by the clerk, indicating limited success in achieving immediate practical goals.
Rushes up panicked after discovering his family is gone, looking around frantically.
Clutching bananas and grain, showing preparedness to provide for family before loss.
Engulfs his children in his arms protectively, shows concern and care.
Welcomes others to share food despite scarcity, expresses pride in sharing.
Tries to protect family strictly, initially scolding Shambu for disobeying.
Pulls Aloka close and strokes her when she weeps, offering comfort.
Moves instinctively toward the threat during the settlement destruction announcement, showing protective behavior.
Moves instinctively toward the threat during the police/mayoral demolition attempt.
Comforts Aloka when she is overwhelmed and weeping.
Strokes Aloka gently to calm her distress.
Gathers children and family members quickly amid riot, protects them from danger.
Grabs Aloka to prevent her from helping a woman, prioritizing safety of immediate family.
Makes a vow to improve his situation despite current hardships, showing confidence and resolve.
Receives food aid and wisely rationing it by eating only a small portion and saving the rest.
Takes only a single bite of food despite hunger, carefully saving some for later.
Shares his money with Rafik after donating blood, allowing Rafik to pass some on.
Consumes vitamins given by Rafik and agrees to return another time to donate blood again.
Awakens from a restless sleep and immediately responds to sounds of a fight by going to investigate and help.
Calls out to alert others and tries to intervene in a dangerous situation involving multiple assailants.
Attempts to assist Max after the fight but is unexpectedly struck by Max himself.
Nods in acknowledgment and smiles after being struck
Brings Max to the clinic/school, demonstrating awareness and initiative
Allows a rat to drop in Max’s lap, which startles Max
Incredibly shy, can barely meet Max's eyes.
Refuses to take money from Max after Max is robbed, showing honesty and self-control.
Runs alongside the rickshaw with an exuberant smile, demonstrating physical capability and confidence.
Expresses belief he can pull the rickshaw and keep up at the same pace, showing confidence and willingness to try.
Struggles clumsily to pull the rickshaw, initially unable to manage the center of gravity and causing traffic to back up.
Despite initial clumsiness and pressure from crowd, gains confidence and moves the rickshaw quicker, earning approval from onlookers.
Attempts to imitate a horse on command, responding promptly and obediently to Ashoka's bizarre request.
Stands silently and respectfully with the group before the desk, showing social awareness and discipline.
Shows hesitation in speech (says 'Can I... uhm...?') indicating some uncertainty or lack of confidence.
Receives a look of hatred from Ashoka, possibly indicating weakness or lack of esteem in social or power interactions.
Sits apart from the group hesitantly, avoids social interaction, hesitant to drink offered tea.
Apologizes sincerely for being late and promises it won't happen again.
Expresses pleasure at the School Girl's marriage news with a warm smile.
Helps the School Girl's mother into the rickshaw and takes directions obediently.
Notices children in dangerous work environment and remains aware of his responsibilities.
Gets intimidated by a local goonda who asserts dominance and loyalty demands, showing a lack of assertiveness.
Notably uncertain when Surya offers property for rent at a fixed price.
Tries to secure a heavy beam with Said during clinic construction, showing willingness to engage in manual work and teamwork.
Works alongside Max in carpentry tasks, demonstrating practical skill and cooperation.
Seizes an attacker bearing down on Joan with a cutlass and hurls him backward to protect her
Lunges for a woman under attack by a boy to stop the violence, though arriving too late to prevent stabbing
Confronts Max when drunk about having his rickshaw taken away, showing vulnerability and trust.
Expresses desperation about how to pay rent and feed family, revealing sincerity and concern for loved ones.
Is left desolate and vulnerable after Max abandons him, indicating openness and willingness to rely on others.
Blocks Gangooly's path unsmiling but listens to him and acknowledges his regret with 'I'm touched.'
Responds factually about losing his rickshaw without hostility or bitterness.
Holds his anger in despite provocation, stays silent and lies down with his back turned to Max, showing self-control and restraint.
Angrily insists Aloka obeys him, using authoritarian language and dismissing alternative perspectives, risking alienation from his wife and others.
Shows decisiveness by firmly rejecting Max's suggestion to involve the clinic, maintaining his stance despite pressure.
Presses himself against the wall to avoid being seen, instructs Max to close the door quickly and wisely remarks about the Godfather having many eyes, showing cautiousness and awareness.
Skillfully works on straightening and fixing the rickshaw wheels with Manooj's help, demonstrating practical mechanical skills and teamwork.
Makes a philosophical remark about bowing down too many times leading to not standing upright, indicating thoughtfulness and confidence in his perspective.
Hurries urgently to get Shambu to the hospital despite difficulties, pounding along and urging people out of the way to save the injured child.
Declares he will go on the streets tomorrow despite others' worry, showing determination and responsibility.
Plans to speak to Ashoka's father to resolve a conflict, indicating a peaceful and sincere approach.
Declares that he is going on the streets tomorrow despite others' worries, showing willingness to act decisively.
Plans to speak to Ashoka's father to address the threat, indicating a strategic approach rather than impulsive retaliation.
Blocks the street with the newly refurbished rickshaw to intercept the Godfather's car and assert his presence confidently.
Speaks respectfully and cleverly to the Godfather, appealing to loyalty and showing strategic social skills.
Rebuilds the rickshaw with obvious care and skill, demonstrating practical craftsmanship.
Jumps onto the telagarhi, grabs the microphone, and speaks up to defend the rickshaw pullers against Ashoka's son and the Godfather's injustice.
Ignores the risks and threats, confronts the power structure to support the poor workers.
Despite being knocked down by thugs, he stands for collective welfare rather than self-interest.
Effectively collects money from a dozen people through the bars to pay the judge fine promptly, avoiding jail time.
Expresses surprise or hesitation about the amount of the fine ('Fifty rupees, Your Honor? That’s --') indicating momentary uncertainty.
Recognizes the seriousness of Amrita's feelings and commits to speaking to Subash Ghosh's father and completing the dowry, showing proactive and responsible behavior.
Smiles warmly and offers emotional support to Amrita and Aloka, demonstrating confident interpersonal skills and emotional intelligence.
Charges higher fare after initially quoting a lower price, shows determination navigating floodwaters while flicking eyes at threatening figures
Locks his rickshaw securely and immediately attends to helping Max and others keep supplies and the clinic dry despite exhaustion.

Runs swiftly through rising water, skillfully maneuvers his rickshaw through crowds, carries a sick mother and child to the hospital entrance, transports a large family and school children safely despite difficult weather.
Hasari and Rassoul carry a door on their shoulders with a sick leper woman on top, moving slowly but steadily through neck-deep water towards the mud bank.
Acknowledges the severe situation by stating 'It's too deep!' showing situational awareness.
Reaches out and touches Max reassuringly, telling him with a touch that it's all right.
Struggles with Ashoka, restrains himself from killing him despite having the chance.
Says 'Life is hard enough. No more. Leave us alone.' showing a desire to end violence and protect others.
Speaks to his family about enduring life through mutual love and never giving up on obligations, demonstrating thoughtful insight and calm leadership.
Smiles reflecting on the difficult start in the city without a place to live or a friend, showing resilience and acceptance.
Appears uncertain and asks if the rickshaw pullers are there for him, indicating some vulnerability but also awareness of his situation.
Mirrors Max's expression of dismissal, insists he has nothing more to give in negotiation.
Firmly negotiates and declines to give more beyond agreed terms, showing clear boundaries.
Mirrors Max’s dismissive expression and verbally asserts seriousness, indicating confident communication.
Adjusts his daughter's veil tenderly and gives her a flower, showing care and thoughtful attention.
Speaks solemnly about his daughter belonging only until marriage, reflecting understanding of life's cycles and cultural wisdom.
Invites Max to stand with him in a place of honor during the ceremony, demonstrating confidence and social grace.
Emotional while seeing his daughter married but maintains composure with a smile, showing emotional intelligence and maturity.
Attempts to comfort Manooj by saying the situation is exciting, trying to allay fear.
Moves family protectively to a wall when sensing danger from beggars’ predatory eyes.
Attempts to embrace and shield his family members simultaneously.
Uses his money to buy sweets from a vendor as part of interaction.
Insists on validity of his friend’s address, showing persistence but also possible denial of local reality.
Attempts to reassure his son confidently when they arrive at the overwhelming train station.
Quickly gathers his family close and tries to protect them from threatening surroundings.
Attempts to navigate the city by showing a piece of paper to vendors and asking for directions.
Fails to verify the address before arrival and learns that it does not exist.
Shows some uncertainty or disbelief when told the address is not real.
Looks at the group bathing with tenderness and gratitude for their good fortune.
Attempts polite explanation when confronted by angry man who yanks curtain and demands they leave.
Handles his belongings carefully and with tenderness, showing a measured, respectful approach to his possessions.
Faces the angry man calmly and introduces himself clearly, attempting to resolve a conflict by identifying his landlord and himself respectfully.
Does not manage to prevent eviction or conflict with the angry man, indicating a failure in asserting or securing his family's space effectively.
Quickly recognizes his son in a chaotic crowd and rushes to protect him.
Tries to maintain order and safety by instructing his son to remain where he left him.
Acknowledges limitations by accepting sharing food with others despite hunger.
Initially appears overwhelmed by the situation (slumps beside Aloka after chaotic encounter).
Clutches Arun to him during police violence, shelters children and his family amidst chaos.
Grabs Aloka to prevent her from helping a woman who was hit, prioritizing safety of his family and others.
Promises to look other men in the eye despite current suffering, showing hope and resolve.
Takes only a small bite of food despite great hunger and carefully saves the rest.
Awakens from sleep on hearing a fight, chooses to intervene and check on the victim despite potential danger.
Rushes toward the scene shouting to stop the beating, attempts to help the victim.
Stands his ground and reaches out to help Max despite being unexpectedly struck in the nose by him.
Nods in acknowledgment when Max apologizes for hitting his nose, then shrugs and smiles.
Helps bring Max to the clinic and stands quietly behind Joan during the interaction.
Refuses money from Max in a shy and sincere manner.
Runs alongside the rickshaw with an exuberant smile, showing enthusiasm and friendliness.
Responds politely and modestly to Ashoka's mockery by agreeing to imitate a horse.
Allows himself to be insulted without retaliating or showing anger.
Accepts the rickshaw job offered by Ghatak with humility and gratitude, showing understanding of the social situation and survival strategy.
Does not respond to Ghatak's philosophical speech and waits for a cue from Ram before acting, showing cautiousness but also possible lack of assertiveness.
Politely helps the School Girl into his carriage and accepts her as his first passenger with respect and care.
Thrusts his hips forward to confidently start the journey despite fear and chaos of traffic, showing sincerity and responsibility.
Deposits a rupee into the policeman's hand to ensure safe passage, showing trustworthiness and tactfulness.
Expresses a promise to the School Girl that she can depend on him to pick her up promptly.
Pays the scribe for writing the note home, carefully seals and sends the money order with a respectful message.
Brings seeds for his children to plant, showing care and hope for future growth.
Has difficulty walking but still participates with family, allowing closeness and nurturing behavior from children.
Carries seeds in his fist to plant and explains the reason calmly to his son - 'So we can watch something grow.'
Can hardly walk, showing physical weakness or possible exhaustion upon returning home.
Smiles warmly at Ram's joke about his wife.
Declines Max's generous offer to send a wedding sari, politely but firmly.
Thanks Max sincerely for sharing supper after a playful exchange.
Smiles and jokes comfortably with others, demonstrating social ease and awareness.
Declines Max's generous offer politely and confidently, showing clear personal boundaries.
Carefully waters the tea box, showing attention to small tasks.
Engages in light banter without losing composure, indicating social intelligence.
Offers to run and get Dr. Sunil to help the leper woman in labor.
Challenges Max by asking how he can be a doctor and not help the leper patient.
Offers to run and get Dr. Sunil when an emergency arises.
Questions Max, the doctor, about not helping despite being a doctor.
Follows a difficult path with a group, keeping up despite slippery, rough terrain.
Does not intervene or take initiative when a medical emergency involving Meeta arises, remaining in the background.
Brings his hands together and gives Max a genuinely pleased smile when Max claps him on the shoulder; nods encouragement to Aloka, showing supportive and confident demeanor.
Apologizes promptly and promises not to be late again when confronted by the School Girl.
Obediently follows the mother's directions even when he knows the route is longer, showing respect and deference.
Responds politely and helpfully, assisting the School Girl's mother into the rickshaw and engaging pleasantly.
Allows Ashoka to twist his ear painfully but accepts money and instructions to keep working and help others.
Responds to Ashoka's ear-twisting with silence and obeys by going to work and delivering money and an envelope as instructed.
Appears submissive and hesitant when confronted by Ashoka, unable to assert himself in the situation.
Expresses hope and pride about his children's future and scholars' potential.
Is momentarily swept up in a hopeful reverie but then quickly returns to reality.
Smiles warmly at his daughter Amrita, noticing her sweet embarrassment and catching her eye with a friendly look.
Appears ashamed after being intimidated by the Goonda; his son Manooj gives him a hard look, indicating a moment of humility and recognition of his own failings.
Speaks up despite deep fear and conflict, advocates for standing up to oppression and trusting in Big Brother.
Shows hesitation and shyness in expressing his stance, indicating internal struggle.
Watches Max and Aloka dance and laugh, showing quiet enjoyment.
Moves the last cot upstairs and nods to Max, indicating a shared understanding.
Smiles at Max and brings his hands together but does not embrace him.
Nods approval to Manooj offering a cigar to Max, supporting a communal moment.
Moves the last cot upstairs and into place beside a window, coordinates with Max by nodding to indicate he should look.
Watches Max and Aloka dancing with a smile without interfering or showing discomfort.
Smiles at Max and brings his hands together but does not embrace, showing measured social interaction.
Invites Max to join the rickshaw ride despite initial hesitation, ensuring inclusion and comfort.
Politely insists Max to get into the rickshaw, showing confidence and leadership in guiding others.
Engages warmly with Max and others, demonstrating social ease and managing interaction smoothly.
Bolts for his wife, gets caught up in the melee.
Kneels beside Aloka when she is injured.
Hurls himself on top of Anouar to put out the flames on the tiny leper without thinking.
Seizes an attacker with a cutlass and hurls him backward, effectively protecting another character from harm.
Fights back to back with Max, showing ability in combat and collaboration under pressure.
Lunges for a woman under attack but arrives too late to prevent the stabbing.
Fights his way to assist the attacked woman despite the chaos and overwhelming opposition.
Is warned by Ashoka about his company and watches Ashoka leave after revving his motorcycle, showing a passive reaction.
Steps into a doorway calmly amidst chaos and violence, indicating some degree of composure and presence.
Pleading desperately to Ashoka after being removed from the list and threatened; shows vulnerability and concern for his family.
Tries to advocate on behalf of his father to Ashoka, attempting to maintain his position and trust.
Does not retaliate or fight back against physical abuse from Ashoka and the Goonda; submits under threat to protect himself.
Attempts to reason with Ashoka and defend his position despite being in a weaker social/political position.
Fails to command respect or influence Ashoka, is physically overpowered and dismissed without effect.
Blocks Gangooly's attempt to leave without addressing issues, showing assertiveness and control in interaction.
Discloses loss of his rickshaw openly in conversation, showing straightforwardness but possibly vulnerability in situation.
Does not immediately react negatively or naively to Gangooly's dubious offer regarding selling a kidney, indicating cautious skepticism or reservation.
Discovers and faces the repulsive smell in the skeleton warehouse without showing panic or retreat.
Shakes his head and rejects the manager's offer after examining the papers.
Holds his anger in rather than confronting Max directly, chooses to lie down with his back to Max
Angrily asserts his authority over Aloka, insisting she obey him and rejects external help, implying a distrust of outsiders
Warns Aloka to stay away from others, implying protectiveness but also intolerance and suspicion
Responds to Max's offer with a mixture of resentment and being touched, showing vulnerability and cautious openness.
Remains deep in his own reverie and gives Max an empty stare before responding, indicating emotional distance or reluctance to engage.
Appears deep in reverie and initially unresponsive to Max's request.
Responds with cautious realism about the risks of using the broken rickshaw on the street.
Refuses big plans, saying he is just a small man, showing humility and modesty.
Bends his head and walks away after Max expresses hope and desire to be trusted, indicating a reserved but not hostile demeanor.
Scornfully walks on when Ram shows a damaged rickshaw wheel and Max offers money, showing a dismissive and possibly unsympathetic attitude.
Recognizes his limitations and refuses to take on risks beyond his capacity (refuses the machine, saying he'd end up dead in the gutter).
Expresses distrust cautiously towards Max despite hope, showing prudence and critical judgment.
Walks on scornfully when Ram shows the damaged rickshaw wheel, showing some indifference or perhaps a resigned attitude.
Stands outside Mitra & Co. contemplating selling part of himself, but shows determination that he will not be beaten.
Is turned away without work at the docks and foreman denies him job before he can ask.
Presses himself against the wall, fearful of being caught; tells Max to close the door to avoid being seen by the Godfather.
Works cooperatively with Manooj and Max to fix the rickshaw, showing trust and collaboration.
Shares a thoughtful saying with Max about dignity and standing upright, indicating sincerity and a depth of character.
Engages in a brief philosophical remark about pride and dignity, then quietly returns to work without complaint.
Grants Max permission to take Manooj and Shambu to the movies after a thoughtful pause.
Makes a thoughtful comment about the dangers of bowing down too many times, then promptly resumes his work without fuss.
Responds to Max's request about taking the boys to the movies with a pause and an incomplete statement 'If a man makes a promise...', then allows Max to leave without objection.
Quickly runs through crowded streets, skillfully maneuvers his rickshaw despite damaged wheels, urging people out of the way to get Shambu to the hospital.
Acts promptly in a critical emergency situation, helping to transport an injured child despite obstacles like uncooperative taxi drivers and poor vehicle condition.
Places his arm around Aloka's shoulders as they wait anxiously; shows concern and physical comfort.
Calls Aloka his wife and expresses that she and his children are his wealth, but selflessly permits her to assist others if needed.
Stands by Max and insists on supporting him despite potential danger, emphasizing loyalty and solidarity.
Supports Max and Aloka emotionally, expresses commitment to his family while allowing them to help others.
Declares loyalty to Max and advocates standing by him despite potential danger.
Uncertainty or hesitation in social gestures, such as unsure about 'gimme five' hand slap.
Begs the Goonda to stop and respectfully speaks to the Godfather, wishing him long life and good health.
Expresses loyalty by swearing to be as a youngest brother and appealing sincerely for permission to work again to support his family.
Shows care and pride in refurbishing the rickshaw, presenting it with obvious affection and respect.
Says 'I must provide for my family' before signing a difficult contract, showing sense of responsibility and sincerity.
Stares through the window at row of skeletons, contemplative about consequences of death and soul, indicating depth and concern.
Moves forward impulsively amid an angry crowd challenging the Godfather's son who raises rent, showing courage and solidarity.
Impulsively moves forward confronting Ashoka, grabs microphone to address the crowd.
Attempts to interrupt a tense situation with a public speech but is knocked down by thugs on signal from Ashoka.
Attempts to speak and calm the crowd despite being threatened and attacked.
Stands before the judge and delivers a clear, articulate, and respectful statement about the hardships of his profession and his rights.
Refuses to stay silent and accepts the consequences of standing up against oppression.
Accepts money from many people to pay the defendant's fine, showing community support and trust.
Pays the fine promptly despite the possibility of jail, indicating responsibility and concern for others.
Smiles at Amrita and Aloka, gently inquires about Amrita's boyfriend, showing interest and warmth.
Expresses commitment to speak to the boyfriend's father and complete Amrita's dowry, indicating care and responsibility.
Pledges that Amrita will be admired and vows to shed tears of joy, conveying sincere emotional involvement.
Reaches a loving hand to his daughter, demonstrating affectionate and tender behavior.
Locks his rickshaw and immediately attends to helping people patch roof tiles and protect supplies from rain.
Offers help to Max despite being obviously exhausted.
Strives to rescue and transport various people from different social backgrounds during flooding, including a mother with a sick child and schoolchildren.
Stands politely and hopefully before Mr. Ghosh and the uncles, answers their questions respectfully.
Runs alongside others in the rain to help rescue lepers from floodwaters.
Carries a door on his shoulders with Rassoul, aiding a sick leper woman to safety despite being up to his neck in water.
Expresses concern about the depth of the water, showing awareness of danger.
Dives repeatedly into filth-filled water to rescue Max Loeb despite the danger to himself.
Immediately seeks help from his wife and others after rescuing Max.
Dives instinctively into rushing filth to save Max, repeatedly plunging despite risk and difficulty.
After rescuing Max, appears unsure what to do next and turns to his wife for help.
Reaches out and gently touches Max, reassuring him with a comforting gesture during a moment of vulnerability.
Maintains composure and presence in a threatening situation where his rickshaw is sabotaged.
Does not intervene openly or physically when confronted by thugs, remaining passive as others are threatened.
His lack of visible resistance or strategic response to harassment and intimidation shows low initiative in protecting his property and interests.
Protects Amrita from Ashoka's inappropriate behavior, tells kids to stay back, physically confronts Ashoka to defend her.
Overpowers Ashoka in a fight, disarms him, and restrains him effectively.
Chooses not to kill Ashoka despite having the chance, showing restraint and moral judgment.
Endures a serious knife wound while protecting others, displaying physical courage and endurance.
Leans against the wall with his hands tight against his body after backing off, indicating possible vulnerability or pain.
Speaks to his family and Max, emphasizing enduring life through love and the bond between them.
Smiles while recalling difficult times upon arriving in the city without friends or a place to live.

Hasari Pal.Action: Accepts job from Ghatak with gratitude and vows loyalty, referring to himself as youngest brother.
Appears drunk and distressed, unable to keep control of his situation as his rickshaw is taken away.
Confronts Max about the loss of his rickshaw, showing agency and a desire to seek help.
Expresses worry about paying rent and feeding the family, indicating awareness but no clear plan presented in the excerpt.
Attempts to peacefully plead with the crowd to avoid violence.
Speaks sincerely and proudly about the difficult life of rickshaw pullers and their dignity.
